brief_summary.textblock:
The purpose of this study is to compare hop performance and jump landing strategy in soccer
      players with higher level sports activities after ACLR using either BPTB or STG and
      controls.

clinical_study.brief_title: Functional Outcome Anterior Cruciate Ligament Reconstruction
clinical_study.condition: Complications of Surgical Procedures or Medical Care

detailed_description.textblock:
The choice of graft for anterior cruciate ligament reconstruction (ACLR) remains
      controversial. Despite the need for outcome studies comparing bone-patellar tendon-bone
      (BPTB) with semitendinosus and gracilis tendon (STG), few studies have evaluated functional
      outcomes. The objective of the current study was to compare hop performance and jump landing
      strategy in soccer players with higher level sports activities after ACLR using either BPTB
      or STG and controls.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  ACLR and controls.

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Musculoskeletal injuries

study_pop.textblock:
The patients with ACL deficiency were invited to participate in a randomized trial
        comparing ACLR with either a BPTB or STG graft.

clinical_study.official_title: Comparison of Functional Outcome Measures of Anterior Cruciate Ligament Reconstruction Using Either Patellar Tendon or Hamstring Tendon Grafts and Controls in Competitive Soccer Players: A Randomized Trial

primary_outcome.measure: Hop values for the both legs in Single, 6-m, Cross-over and Triple hops
primary_outcome.time_frame: Patients were followed up to 8 months post-surgery

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

responsible_party.investigator_affiliation: University of Social Welfare and Rehabilitation Science

secondary_outcome.measure: Landing and Take-off Ground Reaction Forces
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Patients were followed up to 8 months post-surgery
Patients were followed up to 8 months post-surgery

clinical_study.source: University of Social Welfare and Rehabilitation Science

lead_sponsor.agency: University of Social Welfare and Rehabilitation Science

clinical_study.study_design: Observational Model: Case Control, Time Perspective: Prospective
